intro: Hapaloceras wightii, commonly known as the Himalayan false dandelion, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of Central and South Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble a single flower. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, with alternate, lanceolate leaves that are hairy and pubescent. Its flowers are yellow and bloom in clusters, often appearing in late spring to early summer. Hapaloceras wightii is adapted to cold, alpine environments and is often found in rocky or gravelly soils.
